input.code:
### Modelling assumptions
- exchangeability (row/column) -> rotation invariance (spectrum of the matrix)
- low complexity measures for matrices -> (pseudo-) norms on the spectrum
- sparsity for computational efficiency -> low-rank
input.outputFormat:
Modelling assumptions

  • exchangeability (row/column) -> rotation invariance (spectrum of the matrix)
  • low complexity measures for matrices -> (pseudo-) norms on the spectrum
  • sparsity for computational efficiency -> low-rank

Low-Rank Factorization

Y=UVT

input.code:
### Why Low-Rank
We want: A probabilistic model on matrices with:

1) Invariance by permutation of rows and columns

--> The model depends only on the eigenvalues

2) A complexity measure

--> A norm or pseudo-norm (\\(e.g. L_\alpha, \alpha\ge 0\\) ) on the spectrum 

3) Fast to compute and memory efficient

--> \\(\alpha\le 1\\) (Sparsity-inducing)
input.outputFormat:
Why Low-Rank

We want: A probabilistic model on matrices with:

1) Invariance by permutation of rows and columns

--> The model depends only on the eigenvalues

2) A complexity measure

--> A norm or pseudo-norm (e.g.Lα,α≥0 ) on the spectrum

3) Fast to compute and memory efficient

--> α≤1 (Sparsity-inducing)

input.code:
### Singular Value Decomposition (SVD)

SVD is a n optimal quadratic matrix approximator.

The problem

\\( (\hat{\mathbf{U}}, \hat{\mathbf{V}}) \in \arg\min_{\mathbf{U}\in\Re^{N\times K},\mathbf{V}\in\Re^{M\times K}} \gamma(\mathbf{U},\mathbf{V}) \\)

where

\\(
\gamma(U,V) := \||\mathbf{Y} - \mathbf{U}\mathbf{V}^{T}\||_F^2 
\\)

can be solved by a partial SVD algorithm:

\\(
[\mathbf{U},\mathbf{D},\mathbf{V}] = \texttt{sdvs}(\mathbf{Y},K)
\\)

\\(
\hat{\mathbf{U}} = \mathbf{U}  \texttt{sqrt}(\mathbf{D})
\quad,\quad
\hat{\mathbf{V}} = \mathbf{V}  \texttt{sqrt}(\mathbf{D})
\\)

We can use other algorithms to minimize the same objective.
input.outputFormat:
Singular Value Decomposition (SVD)

SVD is a n optimal quadratic matrix approximator.

The problem

(Û ,V̂ )∈argminU∈ℜN×K,V∈ℜM×Kγ(U,V)

where

γ(U,V):=||Y−UVT||2F

can be solved by a partial SVD algorithm:

[U,D,V]=𝚜𝚍𝚟𝚜(Y,K)

Û =U𝚜𝚚𝚛𝚝(D),V̂ =V𝚜𝚚𝚛𝚝(D)

We can use other algorithms to minimize the same objective.

input.code:
### Stochastic Gradient Descent

Objective:

\\(
\gamma(U,V) := \sum_{(i,j)\in\Omega} (y_{ij} - \langle\mathbf{u}_i,\mathbf{v}_j\rangle)^2 
\\)

Where \\(\Omega=\lbrace 1,\cdots,N\rbrace \otimes \lbrace1,\cdots,M\rbrace \\) 


This is a large sum. We can pick one element and do a gradient step in this direction:

1) Pick \\( (i,j) \\) uniformaly at random in \\(\Omega\\) 

2) Gradient step

\\(\mathbf{u}_i \leftarrow \mathbf{u}_i - \eta (\langle\mathbf{u}_i,\mathbf{v}_j\rangle-y_{ij}) \mathbf{v}_j  \\)

\\(\mathbf{v}_j \leftarrow \mathbf{v}_j - \eta (\langle\mathbf{u}_i,\mathbf{v}_j\rangle-y_{ij}) \mathbf{u}_i \\)

where \\(\eta\\) is the gradient step size (can be adaptive)
input.outputFormat:
Stochastic Gradient Descent

Objective:

γ(U,V):=∑(i,j)∈Ω(yij−⟨ui,vj⟩)2

Where Ω={1,⋯,N}⊗{1,⋯,M}

This is a large sum. We can pick one element and do a gradient step in this direction:

1) Pick (i,j) uniformaly at random in Ω

2) Gradient step

ui←ui−η(⟨ui,vj⟩−yij)vj

vj←vj−η(⟨ui,vj⟩−yij)ui

where η is the gradient step size (can be adaptive)

input.code:
### Alternating Least Squares
The objective
\\(
\gamma(U,V) := \||\mathbf{Y} - \mathbf{U}\mathbf{V}^{T}\||_F^2 
\\)
can also be minimized by block-coordinate descent:

\\(
\arg\min_{\mathbf{u}_i} \gamma(U,V) = \arg\min_{u_i} \||\mathbf{Y}_{i:} - \mathbf{u}_i\mathbf{V}^{T}\||_2^2 
\\)

\\(
\arg\min_{\mathbf{v}_j} \gamma(U,V) = \arg\min_{v_j} \||\mathbf{Y}_{:j} - \mathbf{U}\mathbf{v_j}^{T}\||_2^2 
\\)

Least square problems! ==> Unique solutions:

\\(
\mathbf{u}_i \leftarrow (\mathbf{V}^T\mathbf{V})^{-1} \mathbf{V}^T \mathbf{Y}_{i:} 
\\)


\\(
\mathbf{v}_j \leftarrow (\mathbf{U}^T\mathbf{U})^{-1} \mathbf{U}^T \mathbf{Y}_{:j} 
\\)

Each step can be parallelized efficiently (e.g. Regularized LSA)
input.outputFormat:
Alternating Least Squares

The objective γ(U,V):=||Y−UVT||2F can also be minimized by block-coordinate descent:

argminuiγ(U,V)=argminui||Yi:−uiVT||22

argminvjγ(U,V)=argminvj||Y:j−UvjT||22

Least square problems! ==> Unique solutions:

ui←(VTV)−1VTYi:

vj←(UTU)−1UTY:j

Each step can be parallelized efficiently (e.g. Regularized LSA)
